revision.comment: /* Hollyford Track and tourism */ added image
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=October 2017}} {{use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} '''David John Gunn''', generally known as '''Davey''' or '''Davy''', (18 September 1887 – 25 December 1955) was a keen promoter of the attractions of the [[Hollyford Track]] and from 1936 guided parties to them. A farmer and [[the bush#New Zealand|bushman]] he ran his almost wild cattle in the glacier-cut [[Hollyford River|Hollyford Valley]] in [[Fiordland]], [[Westland District|South Westland]], New Zealand.
Gunn was the fourth of five children of Scottish parents, Isabella Grierson Robertson and her husband, Alexander Gunn. A one-time shepherd,<ref name="DNZB Gunn">{{DNZB|Owen|Alwyn|4g25|Gunn, David John|24 October 2017}}</ref> Alexander Gunn ran a sheep farm of 27,000 acres in Central Otago.<ref name=WDA>[https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/WDA19170517.2.21?query=gunn%20waimate Waimate Daily Advertiser, page 3, 17 May 1917]</ref> For secondary schooling David lived at Hook near [[Waimate]] with his maiden aunts on their 500 acre farm.<ref name=WDA/> Matriculating and leaving school he briefly followed other family members into [[Dalgety and Company|Dalgety's]] working in one of their many branch offices as a clerk before deciding a desk job did not suit him.<ref name=JB>Julia Bradshaw (with Murray Gunn), ''The Land of Doing without, Davey Gunn of the Hollyford'', 2007, Canterbury University Press. {{ISBN|9781877257537}}</ref> He went back to work on and later manage the farm at Hook.<ref name=WDA/> He underwent military training at Trentham in 1918 but was too late to be sent overseas.<ref name=JB/> [[File:Hollyford2036.jpg|thumb|A bridge on Gunn's Hollyford Track]] He went farming on his own account 100 miles south of Waimate at [[Sutton, New Zealand|Sutton]]. On 10 July 1919 at [[Morven, New Zealand|Morven]] near Waimate he married Ethel May Willetts, a confectioner. They were to have two daughters, Isabel and Dorothy, and a son, Murray.
George Gunn, an early runholder, mapped some of the [[Hollyford Valley]] in 1861. In 1926 David Gunn bought freehold land there from remaining original settlers, the McKenzie family. He increased his Hollyford landholding in 1929, just before the onset of the [[Great Depression]], by acquiring four leases totalling more than 25,000 acres. He then moved to the valley, establishing his solitary base at Deadman's Hut on the banks of the [[Hollyford River]]. Gunn cut a number of well used tracks and erected huts in the more remote parts of his run.
His wife took their children to Oamaru to be educated and Gunn returned to his family for brief visits only twice a year. {{NOTOC}} ==Fox Moth crash== Gunn came to public attention on 30 December 1936 with a speedy journey to bring assistance to the injured passengers of a [[de Havilland Fox Moth]] cabin plane he had seen crash into the sea at [[Big Bay, New Zealand|Big Bay]]. He covered the 90-kilometre, four-day journey in just 21 hours, a feat which earned him a [[King George VI Coronation Medal]] the following year. ==Hollyford Track and tourism== [[File:Mt Tutoko, Hollyford Track (5845381298).jpg|thumb|Mt Tutoko, Hollyford Track]] In 1936, Gunn began guiding tramping parties down his [[Hollyford Track]], and would continue doing so until his death in 1955. Friendly and hospitable by nature, and possessing considerable personal charm, Gunn became a well-known and popular figure. He was respected for his bushcraft, his energy, and his knowledge of the area.
On Christmas Day 1955, Gunn was fording the Hollyford River on horseback near [[Hidden Falls (New Zealand)|Hidden Falls]], with a 12-year-old boy mounted behind him. The horse stumbled and fell, and both riders were seen to find their feet in the river, until the horse stood up and they were both swept away and drowned. Gunn's body was never found.
After his death his son, Murray, continued to guide trampers in the area, and started "Gunn's Camp", a rest-stop for trampers with store and small museum, which still stands near the southern end of the track, around 10 km from the [[Milford Sound]]-[[Te Anau]] highway.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{cite web|url=http://www.gunnscamp.org.nz/history-of-gunns-camp|title=History of Gunn's Camp • Gunn's Camp|website=Gunnscamp.org.nz|accessdate=24 October 2017}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/travel/super-tramp-20081113-63py.html|title=Super tramp|website=Smh.com.au|accessdate=24 October 2017}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gunn, David John}} [[Category:1887 births]] [[Category:1955 deaths]] [[Category:New Zealand farmers]] [[Category:New Zealand businesspeople]] [[Category:Fiordland]]

revision.comment: /* Overview */ Corrected factual errors about the origin of "dynamic capabilities" (Nonaka and Takeuchi did not attribute it to Prahalad and Hamel) and cleaned up related text (It was redundant to call out Shuen as an originator since the new text lists her as one of the authors of the initial article..
revision.text:
In [[organizational theory]], '''dynamic capability''' is the capability of an organization to purposefully adapt an organization's resource base. The concept was defined by [[David Teece]], Gary Pisano and Amy Shuen, in their 1997 paper ''Dynamic Capabilities and Strategic Management'', as "the firm’s ability to integrate, build, and reconfigure internal and external competences to address rapidly changing environments".<ref name="Teece et al.">{{cite journal|last2 = Pisano|first2 = Gary|last3 = Shuen|first3 = Amy|date = August 1997|title = Dynamic Capabilities and Strategic Management|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/(SICI)1097-0266(199708)18:7%3C509::AID-SMJ882%3E3.0.CO;2-Z/epdf|journal = [[Strategic Management Journal]]|volume = 18|issue = 7|pages = 509–533|last1 = Teece|first1 = David|doi=10.1002/(sici)1097-0266(199708)18:7<509::aid-smj882>3.0.co;2-z}}</ref>
The term is often used in the plural form, '''dynamic capabilities''', emphasizing that the ability to react adequately and timely to external changes requires a combination of multiple capabilities.
== Overview == The phrase "dynamic capabilities" was introduced in a working paper by [[David Teece]], [[Gary Pisano]], and Amy Shuen.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Teece |first1=David |last2=Pisano |first2=Gary |last3=Shuen |first3=Amy |title=Firm Capabilities, Resources, and the Concept of Strategy |date=1990 |publisher=Center for Research on Management |location=University of California, Berkeley |edition=CCC Working Paper 90–8}}</ref>The final, peer-reviewed version was published in 1997.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Teece |first1=David J. |last2=Pisano |first2=Gary |last3=Shuen |first3=Amy |title=Dynamic capabilities and strategic management |journal=Strategic Management Journal |date=August 1997 |volume=18 |issue=7 |pages=509–533 |doi=10.1002/(SICI)1097-0266(199708)18:7%3C509::AID-SMJ882%3E3.0.CO;2-Z}}</ref>
The idea of dynamic capabilities is similar in some ways to the previously existing concept of operational capabilities; the latter pertains to the current operations of an organization, whereas the former, by contrast, refers to an organization's capacity to efficiently and responsively change these operations and develop its resources.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Helfat|first1=Constance E. |last2=Finkelstein |first2=Sydney |last3=Mitchell |first3=Will |last4=Peteraf |first4=Margaret |last5=Singh |first5=Harbir |last6=Teece |first6=David |last7=Winter |first7=Sidney G. |title=Dynamic Capabilities: Understanding Strategic Change in Organizations |year=2009 |publisher=John Wiley & Sons |isbn=9781405182065 |url= https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=u0Tuh5vixLkC&oi=fnd&pg=PR6&dq=%22Dynamic+Capabilities:+Understanding+strategic+change+in+organizations |accessdate=7 December 2017}}</ref>
The main assumption of this framework is that an organization's basic competencies should be used to create short-term competitive positions that can be developed into longer-term competitive advantage. Nelson and Winter, in their 1982 book ''An Evolutionary Theory of Economic Change'', link the growth of the concept of dynamic capabilities to the [[resource-based view]] of the firm and the concept of "routines" in evolutionary theories of organization.<ref name="Nelson1982">{{cite book|first=Richard R. |last=Nelson |title=An Evolutionary Theory of Economic Change |year=1982 |publisher=Belknap Press of Harvard University Press |isbn=978-0-674-27228-6}}</ref> Douma and Scheuder describe it as a bridge between the economics-based strategy literature and evolutionary approaches to organizations.<ref name="DoumaSchreuder2002">{{cite book|last1=Douma |first1=Sytse |authorlink1=Sytse Douma |last2=Schreuder |first2=Hein |authorlink2=Hein Schreuder |title=Economic Approaches to Organizations |edition=Third |year=2002 |publisher=Financial Times Prentice Hall |isbn=9780273651994}}</ref>
The resource-based view of the firm emphasizes sustainable competitive advantage; the dynamic capabilities view, on the other hand, focuses more on the issue of competitive survival in response to rapidly changing contemporary business conditions. Strategy scholars Gregory Ludwig and Jon Pemberton, in one of the few empirical studies on the topic, called for clarification of the specific processes of dynamic capability building in particular industries to make the concept more useful to senior managers who set directions for their firms.<ref name="Ludwig 2011 pp.215-236">{{cite journal|last1=Ludwig|first1=Gregory |last2=Pemberton |first2=Jon |title=A managerial perspective of dynamic capabilities in emerging markets: The case of the Russian steel industry |journal=Journal for East European Management Studies |issn=0949-6181 |year=2011 |volume=16 |issue=3 |pages=215–236 |jstor= 23281688}}</ref>
Dynamic capabilities theory concerns the development of strategies for senior managers of successful companies to adapt to radical discontinuous change, while maintaining minimum capability standards to ensure competitive survival. For example, industries which have traditionally relied on a specific manufacturing process can't always change this process on short notice when a new technology arrives; when this happens, managers need to adapt their own routines to make the most of their existing resources while simultaneously planning for future process changes as the resources depreciate.<ref name="Ludwig 2011 pp.215-236"/>
The New Dynamic Capabilities framework, posed by Amy Shuen in her analysis of Web 2.0, focuses on the firm's ability to quickly orchestrate and reconfigure externally sourced competences,ranging from Apple, Google Android, IBM Linux developer ecosystems to crowdsourced, crowdfunded open innovations such as the Obama08 mobile app—while leveraging internal resources such as platforms, know-how, user communities and digital, social and mobile networks.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Shuen |first1=Amy |last2=Sieber |first2=Sandra |title=Orchestrating the New Dynamic Capabilities |journal=IESE Insight Review|date=2009 |issue=3 |pages=58–65 |url= http://www.ieseinsight.com/review/articulo.aspx?doc=5445&seccion=6 |accessdate=7 December 2017 |doi=10.15581/002.art-1605}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Shuen |first=Amy |title=Web 2.0: A Strategy Guide: Business thinking and strategies behind successful Web 2.0 implementations |year=2008 |publisher=O'Reilly Media |isbn=9780596553753}}</ref> The New Dynamic Capabilities framework takes into account digital, information and network economics<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shapiro |first1=Carl |last2=Varian |first2=Hal R. |title=Information Rules: A Strategic Guide to the Network Economy |year=1998 |publisher=Harvard Business Review Press |isbn=9780875848631}}</ref> and the fall of the transaction costs of involved in using specialized services.<ref>{{cite web|last=Williamson |first=Oliver E. |title=Nobel Prize Lecture: Transaction Cost Economics: The Natural Progression |url= https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/economic-sciences/laureates/2009/williamson-lecture.html |website=nobelprize.org |date=8 December 2009 |accessdate=7 December 2017}}</ref> According to Philip Cordes-Berszinn, though, more research is needed in order to measure the "capabilities" and to appropriately apply the ideas to practical management situations.<ref name=berszinn>{{cite book|last1=Cordes-Berszinn|first1=Philip|title=Dynamic Capabilities: How Organisational Structures Affect Knowledge Processes|date=November 2013|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|url=http://www.palgrave.com/page/detail/dynamic-capabilities-philip-cordesberszinn/?K=9781137351272|accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref>
== Processes == A detailed description of processes and theoretical roots is provided by Arndt, Pierce, and Teece (2017). Teece, Pisano, and Shuen proposed three dynamic capabilities as necessary for an organization to meet new challenges: the ability of employees to learn quickly and to build new strategic assets; the integration of these new strategic assets, including capability, technology and customer feedback, into company processes; and lastly the transformation or reuse of existing assets which have depreciated.<ref name="Teece et al."/><ref name="Eisenhardt and Martin">{{cite journal|last1= Eisenhardt|first1= Kathleen M.|last2= Martin|first2= Jeffrey A.|title=Dynamic capabilities:What are they? |url= http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/1097-0266%28200010/11%2921:10/11%3C1105::AID-SMJ133%3E3.0.CO;2-E/abstract |journal=Strategic Management Journal |volume= 21 |issue=10/11 |pages=1105–1122 |publisher=Wiley-Blackwell |date=October 2000|doi=10.1002/1097-0266(200010/11)21:10/11<1105::AID-SMJ133>3.0.CO;2-E |accessdate=7 December 2017}}</ref> Teece refers to successful implementation of these three stages as developing "corporate agility".<ref name="dynamic">{{cite journal|last=Teece|first=David J.|title=Explicating Dynamic Capabilities: The Nature and Microfoundations of (Sustainable) Enterprise Performance |url= http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/smj.640/abstract |journal=Strategic Management Journal |volume= 28 |issue=13 |pages=1319–1350 |publisher=John Wiley & Sons |date=August 2007 |doi=10.1002/smj.640 |accessdate=7 December 2017}}</ref>
===Learning=== The first stage, learning, requires employees and managers to reorganize their routines to promote interactions that lead to successful solutions to particular problems, to recognize and avoid dysfunctional activity and strategic blind spots, and to make appropriate use of alliance and acquisition to bring new strategic assets into the firm from external sources. A practical example of this is provided by Jean-Pierre Jeannet and [[Hein Schreuder]], in their book ''From Coal to Biotech'', which lays out how the Dutch company [[DSM (company)|DSM]] transformed itself twice using 'strategic learning cycles'.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Jeannet |first1=Jean-Pierre |first2=Hein |last2=Schreuder |year=2015 |title=From Coal to Biotech: The transformation of DSM with business school support |publisher=Springer |isbn=9783662462980}}</ref>
=== New assets === In his 1988 book ''Managing Quality'', [[David A. Garvin]] states that quality performance depends on organisational routines for gathering and processing information, for linking customer experiences with engineering design choices and for coordinating factories and component suppliers.<ref name="Garvin1988">{{cite book|first=David A. |last=Garvin |title=Managing Quality: The Strategic and Competitive Edge|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K-LWY2qgSHwC|year=1988|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-0-02-911380-6|page=204}}</ref> Increasingly competitive advantage also requires the integration of external activities and technologies through alliances and partnerships.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Zahra |first1=Shaker A. |last2=Nielsen |first2=Anders P. |title=Sources of capabilities, integration and technology commercialization |journal=Strategic Management Journal |date=1 May 2002 |volume=23 |issue=5 |pages=377–398 |doi=10.1002/smj.229 |url= http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/smj.229/abstract |issn=1097-0266 |accessdate=7 December 2017}}</ref>
=== Transformation of existing assets === Economists Amit and Schoemaker pointed out in 1993 that success in fast changing markets depends on reconfiguring the firm’s asset structure to accomplish rapid internal and external transformation.<ref>{{cite book|last=Khalid |first=Saba |title=Exploring Firm Level Market Knowledge Competence and Its Implications for the Speed and Success of Export Expansion: A Mixed Methodology Study from the Software Industry|date=2009|publisher=University of Vaasa|isbn=9789524762700|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=afJT6sXTyroC&pg=PA25 |page=25|accessdate=7 December 2017}}</ref> Firms must develop processes to make changes inexpensively while accomplishing reconfiguration and transformation ahead of the competition. This can be supported by decentralization, local autonomy and strategic alliances.
===Co-specialization === Another "dynamic capabilities" concept is co-specialization. For example, the physical assets, human resources and the intellectual property of a company, having developed together over time, are more valuable in combination than separately, and give a firm a sustainable competitive advantage.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Douma |first1=Sytse |authorlink1=Sytse Douma |last2=Schreuder |first2=Hein |authorlink2=Hein Schreuder |title=Economic Approaches to Organisations |year=2013 |publisher=Pearson |isbn=9780273735298 |edition=Fifth |url= https://www.amazon.com/Economic-Approaches-Organisations-Sytse-Douma/dp/0273735292}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Corporate foresight]] * [[Resource-based view]] * [[Theory of the firm]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==Further reading== * Arndt, Felix and Pierce, Lamar. 2017. The behavioral and evolutionary roots of dynamic capabilities. Industrial and Corporate Change. forthcoming. * {{cite journal | last1 = Barreto | first1 = Ilídio | year = 2010 | title = Dynamic Capabilities: A Review of Past Research and an Agenda for the Future | url = | journal = Journal of Management | volume = 36 | issue = 1| pages = 256–280 | doi=10.1177/0149206309350776}} * Ludwig, Gregory and Pemberton, Jon (2011). "A managerial perspective of dynamic capabilities in emerging markets: the case of the Russian steel industry", Journal of East European Management Studies, 16(3), pp. 215–236. ISSN 0949-6181 * Najda-Janoszka, Marta (2016). Dynamic capability-based approach to value appropriation. Krakow: Jagiellonian University Press.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dynamic Capabilities}} [[Category:Management]] [[Category:Organizational theory]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/180.249.225.150|180.249.225.150]] ([[User talk:180.249.225.150|talk]]) to last revision by 174.106.230.31. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
An '''End-user certificate''', or '''EUC''', is a document used in international transfers, including sales and arms provided as aid, of [[weapons]] and [[ammunition]] to certify that the buyer is the final recipient of the materials, and is not planning on transferring the materials to another party. EUCs are required by many governments to restrict the flow of the materials to undesired destinations, such as [[embargo]]ed states or rebel groups, governments with bad human rights records or states which are considered a threat by the original supplier of the arms.
There are several problems with EUCs as a means to prevent undesirable [[arms exports]]. EUCs can be [[forgery|forged]] or falsified; they can also be obtained from [[corrupt]] officials, therefore there is a need for EUCs that are difficult to forge.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://books.sipri.org/files/insight/SIPRIInsight1003.pdf |title=End-User Certificates: Improving standards to prevent diversion |accessdate=2010-09-05}}</ref> Another problem is that an EUC does not guarantee that the arms recipient will actually live up to its promise not to re-transfer the weapons received. EUCs which are not backed up by proper end-use monitoring are weak.
In 1936-1938, German arms were supplied to both sides in the [[Spanish Civil War]] via Greece using Greek then Mexican end-user certificates, see [[Pyrkal]]. ==References== <references />
[[Category:Arms control]] [[Category:Military industry]] [[Category:Weapons trade]]
{{weapon-stub}} {{law-term-stub}}

{{unreferenced|date=November 2013}} '''François Jean Baptiste Marie "Franz" Colruyt''' (14 December 1901, [[Lembeek]] - 4 November 1958, [[Halle, Belgium|Halle]])<ref>[http://www.mandlonline.com/IMG/pdf/archives_mm_ef_entreprise.pdf Short biography]</ref> is the founder of the Colruyt family business. Under his leadership, a business in colonial goods evolved into a wholesale business in dry food.
== Family == {{main|Colruyt family}} Franz Colruyt was the second son in a family of 11 children. His father Joseph was a baker and had a store under the church tower of Lembeek (a borough of [[Halle,_Belgium|Halle]]). After his death, his son [[Jo Colruyt]] took over the company.
==Career== Franz Colruyt started working with his father and delivered food to stores and large consumers. In 1928, Franz Colruyt decided to shut down the bakery and start up a wholesale business in colonial goods, such as coffee and spices. Until the war, the wholesale business mainly serves stores around Halle and [[Tubize|Tubeke]].
After WW2, the business booms and new customers are found in and around [[Brussels]]. Franz Colruyt also starts bottling wine and roasting coffee. The family business grows into a food wholesaler.
In 1950, Franz Colruyt founds the "Etablissementen Franz Colruyt nv" with a capital of 5 million francs (€ 125,000). His brothers Henri and Jules are also part of the business.
In the 1950s, the first mini-supermarkets and supermarkets open in Belgium. As a reaction to this, Franz Colruyt opens the Boni stores. These are run by independent shopkeepers that buy goods from Colruyt.
In 1958, his son Jo Colruyt takes over the company with his brothers. At that time, the company is already delivering to about 800 small independent stores and has about 150 employees.
==Personal== Franz Colruyt had a lot of attention for matters such as work simplification, efficiency, simplicity and working with production lines. This was also a necessity. He started his business during a crisis year. He concluded that low prices and low costs could help the company.
==References== <references />

([[North America|NA]]), 2006 ([[Europe|EU]]) |genre = [[Strategy]], [[simulation]] |modes = [[Single-player]] |platforms = [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] }} '''''Freight Tycoon''''' is a [[strategy game#Simulation|simulation strategy]] [[computer and video game|computer game]] focused around transporting goods via small and large tonnage trucks. The game was published by the [[Russia]]n [[1C Company]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Joachim Froholt|title=Freight Tycoon Inc.|url=http://www.gamer.no/artikler/10177/freight-tycoon-inc/|accessdate=24 October 2012|newspaper=Gamer.no|date=March 1, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Tobias Lange|title=Truck Tycoon E3-Rendertrailer|url=http://www.krawall.de/web/Truck_Tycoon/news/id,26111/s,,|accessdate=24 October 2012|newspaper=KGN|date=July 21, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Michał Urbanek|title=Truck Tycoon - poradnik do gry|url=http://poradniki.gracza.pl/poradnik.asp?ID=16642|date=December 8, 2006|accessdate=24 October 2012|newspaper=GRYOnline|format=PDF}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Freight Tycoon|url=http://www.jeuxpo.com/game_test-21http:/game_test-7417.html|publisher=Jeuxpo|accessdate=24 October 2012}}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Harald Sigurdssøn Astrup | birth_date = {{Birth date|1903|05|29|df=y}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{Death date and age|1983|06|22|1903|05|29|df=y}} | burial_place = [[Ullern]] | nationality = Norwegian | occupation = Businessman
Owner of [[Astrup & Søn]]
Supervisory council member of [[Den norske Creditbank]], [[Dyno Industrier]], [[Norcem]], the [[Norwegian America Line]] and [[Bjølvefossen]] | boards = [[Storebrand]]
[[Livsforsikringsselskapet Idun|Idun]]
[[Christiania Søforsikringsselskab]]
[[Poseidon (insurance)|Poseidon]]
[[Norwegian Museum of Decorative Arts and Design]]
[[Det Norske Selskab (1818)|Det Norske Selskab]] | parents = [[Sigurd Astrup]] (father)
Ingeborg Willumsen (mother) | spouse = Mabel Anette Plathe Butenschøn (m. 1928) | relatives = [[Barthold A. Butenschøn]] (brother-in-law)
[[Barthold A. Butenschøn, Sr.]] (father-in-law)
[[Eivind Astrup|Eivind]] (uncle)
[[Thorvald Astrup]] (uncle) | years_active = 1926-1971 }} '''Harald Sigurdssøn Astrup''' (29 May 1903 – 22 June 1983) was a [[Norway|Norwegian]] businessperson. He was born in [[Oslo|Kristiania]] as a son of politician [[Sigurd Astrup]] (1873–1949) and Ingeborg Willumsen (1877–1962).{{cite encyclopedia|year=1973|title=Astrup, Harald|encyclopedia=[[Hvem er hvem?]]|editor=Steenstrup, Bjørn|publisher=Aschehoug|location=Oslo|url=http://runeberg.org/hvemerhvem/1973/0030.html|page=30|language=Norwegian|accessdate=12 August 2011}} He was named after his paternal grandfather, and was a nephew of [[Henning Astrup (1864–1896)|Henning]], [[Eivind Astrup|Eivind]] and [[Thorvald Astrup]].{{cite encyclopedia|title=Astrup|url=http://www.snl.no/Astrup|encyclopedia=[[Store norske leksikon]]|last=Bratberg|first=Terje|authorlink=Terje Bratberg|publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget|location=Oslo|year=2009|editor-last=Godal|editor-first=Anne Marit|accessdate=31 May 2011|language=Norwegian}} In 1928 he married Mabel Anette Plathe Butenschøn, a sister of [[Barthold A. Butenschøn]] and daughter of [[Barthold A. Butenschøn, Sr.]] He finished his secondary education in 1922, and was a travelling businessman in Norway and abroad until being hired in the family company [[Astrup & Søn]] in 1926. He advanced to office manager in 1931, partner in 1936 and sole owner in 1949; he also served as chairman. He was a board member of the insurance companies [[Storebrand]], [[Livsforsikringsselskapet Idun|Idun]], [[Christiania Søforsikringsselskab]] and [[Poseidon (insurance)|Poseidon]], and was a supervisory council member of [[Den norske Creditbank]], [[Dyno Industrier]], [[Norcem]], the [[Norwegian America Line]] and [[Bjølvefossen]]. He was a board member of the [[Norwegian Museum of Decorative Arts and Design]] and honorary member of [[Det Norske Selskab (1818)|Det Norske Selskab]], which he had chaired from 1960 to 1968. He retired in 1971.{{cite news|title=Harald Astrup (obituary)|last=Hansson|first=Per M.|date=1 July 1983|work=[[Aftenposten]]|page=17|language=Norwegian}} He died in June 1983 and was buried in [[Ullern]].{{cite web|url=http://www.disnorge.no/gravminner/index.php?language=engelsk|title=Cemeteries in Norway|publisher=DIS-Norge|accessdate=12 August 2011}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Astrup, Harald}} [[Category:1903 births]] [[Category:1983 deaths]] [[Category:People from Oslo]] [[Category:Norwegian businesspeople]] [[Category:Norwegian businesspeople in insurance]] {{Norway-business-bio-stub}}

{{Infobox Politician | name = James Moore | image = | caption = | order =[[List of colonial governors of South Carolina|13th Colonial Governor of South Carolina]] | office = | term_start = September 11, 1700 | term_end = March 1703 | preceded =[[Joseph Blake (governor)|Joseph Blake]] | succeeded =[[Nathaniel Johnson (politician)|Nathaniel Johnson]] | birth_date = c. 1650 | birth_place = England | death_date = {{death year and age|1706|1650}} | death_place = | restingplace = | birthname = | spouse = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = | occupation = colonial administrator | religion = <!-- Military service --> | branch = | serviceyears = | rank = | unit = | commands = | battles = | awards = }} [[File:OcmulgeeRaid.JPG|thumbnail|right|Col. Moore leads his raiding party past the Ocmulgee trading-post, in this museum display at [[Ocmulgee National Monument]]]]
'''James Moore''' (c. 1650 – 1706) was the [[Kingdom of England|English]] governor of [[Province of Carolina|colonial Carolina]] between 1700 and 1703. He is best known for leading several invasions of [[Spanish Florida]] during [[Queen Anne's War]], including attacks in 1704 and 1706 which wiped out most of the [[Spanish missions in Florida]].<ref name="Doak2007"/> He captured and brought back to Carolina as slaves thousands of [[Apalachee|Apalachee Indians]].
==Early life== Little is known of James Moore's origins. During his life he was said to be a son of Roger Moore (also known as [[Rory O'Moore]] or Ruairí Óg Ó Mórdha), leader of the [[Irish Rebellion of 1641]] and that he had supposedly inherited his father's rebellious nature.<ref name="Heitzler2005-275"/> He first appears in the records of the [[Province of Carolina]] in 1675 representing Margaret Berringer Yeamans, widow of Sir [[John Yeamans]], before the colonial council. At about the same time he married her daughter by her first husband, also named Margaret.
==Political career==
In 1677, 1682, and 1683, he served on the colonial council. He played a leading role in a 1690 expedition into the Carolina back country, crossing the [[Appalachian Mountains]] to investigate possibilities of trade with the local Indian population. In 1698 he was elected to the colonial assembly, and was described as the right-hand-man of proprietor Sir John Colleton. The next year he was named chief justice of the colony, a post he held until he was named governor in 1700, replacing the deceased [[Joseph Blake (governor)|Joseph Blake]].
James Moore was a leader of one of colonial South Carolina's political factions, called the "Goose Creek Men", after [[Goose Creek, South Carolina|Goose Creek]], an outlying area of [[Charleston, South Carolina|Charleston]].<ref name="Heitzler2005-275">{{cite book|last=Heitzler|first=Michael James|title=Goose Creek, A Definitive History: Volume One, Planters, Politicians and Patriots|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=32l9iEyKUxkC&pg=PA275|accessdate=8 October 2011|year=2005|publisher=The History Press|isbn=978-1-59629-055-6|page=275}}</ref>
In 1683 Moore was granted {{convert|2400|acre}} by the [[Lords Proprietor#Carolina|Lords Proprietors]]. He called his estate "Boochowee". Part of this land is known today as Liberty Hall Plantation.<ref name="Heitzler2005-275"/>
From 1691 Moore was the acknowledged leader of the Goose Creek Men, the main political opposition to the ruling "[[English Dissenters|Dissenter]]" faction. Moore's rise to governorship in 1700 signalled a major shift in the politics of the colony. The Dissenters contested Moore's "unjust election". But the Lords Proprietors saw to it that Moore remained governor, and they made it clear that the Dissenters were no longer in favor.<ref name="Edgar1998">{{cite book|last=Edgar|first=Walter B.|title=South Carolina: a history|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EFSbwGk2szgC&pg=PA93|accessdate=8 October 2011|year=1998|publisher=Univ of South Carolina Press|isbn=978-1-57003-255-4|page=93}}</ref>
Between 1700 and 1703 Moore was the [[British Empire|British]] governor of Carolina, which was then in the process of dividing into the provinces of [[Province of North Carolina|North]] and [[Province of South Carolina|South Carolina]]. During this period, he led a number of attacks from the Carolinas into [[Spanish Florida]]. He relied on allied Indian tribes, especially the [[Yamasee]] for most of his military force. On news of the outbreak of [[Queen Anne's War]] in 1702, he led 500 colonists, 300 native allies, and 14 small ships on an invasion of Spanish Florida along the coast, destroying the remaining Spanish missionary Indians of [[Guale]] and [[Mocama]], and devastating the lands around [[St. Augustine, Florida|St. Augustine]]. While the town of St. Augustine was razed, its central fortress, [[Castillo de San Marcos]], where the Spanish and numerous allied Indians had taken refuge, [[Siege of St. Augustine (1702)|resisted Moore's siege]].<ref name="Doak2007">{{cite book|last=Doak|first=Robin|title=South Carolina 1540-1776|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uWASfc2EuawC&pg=PA48|accessdate=8 October 2011|date=14 August 2007|publisher=National Geographic Books|isbn=978-1-4263-0066-0|page=48}}</ref><ref name="RowlandMoore1996">{{cite book|last1=Rowland|first1=Lawrence Sanders|last2=Moore|first2=Alexander|last3=Rogers|first3=George C.|title=The History of Beaufort County, South Carolina: 1514-1861|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WjdhnfG0tYcC&pg=PA88|accessdate=8 October 2011|year=1996|publisher=Univ of South Carolina Press|isbn=978-1-57003-090-1|pages=88–89}}</ref> The 1702 campaign was viewed as a disaster due to the failure to take the fortress and the expenses incurred, and Moore resigned his post.
In 1704, Moore led an expedition of 50 Englishmen and 1,000 [[Creek people|Creek]], Yamasee, and other allied Indians, into western Florida, leading to the [[Apalachee Massacre]]. The [[Apalachee]] were the last powerful Spanish-allied Indian nation in the region. Their defeat in 1704 resulted in many Apalachee being enslaved and taken from Charleston to the West Indies. Other Apalachee were relocated (some voluntarily, others not) to the [[Savannah River]] to live in semi-serfdom. Another result of the defeat of the Apalachee was the collapse of the final defence of the Indians of Florida. In the following years, Carolinian and Indian slave raiders virtually wiped out the Indian population of Florida all the way to the [[Florida Keys]].
Moore's defeat of the Apalachee in Spanish Florida was hailed as a major victory for Carolina, which had been fighting with the Spanish for control of the region for decades. It also served to strengthen ties between various southeastern Indians and Carolina. The [[Creek people]] and the [[Cherokee]]s became much more closely allied with Carolina. With these two Indian nations as strong allies, the English rose to a position of dominance over the French and Spanish in the American southeast.
Governor Moore died in 1706 of a tropical disease, possibly [[yellow fever]]. He was significantly in debt. His son by the same name was elected to the same office in 1719 following the overthrow of the proprietary governor.
==Family==
James Moore married Margaret Berringer, daughter of Lady Margaret Yeamans (by a previous marriage).<ref name="Heitzler2005-160">{{cite book|last=Heitzler|first=Michael James|title=Goose Creek, A Definitive History: Volume One, Planters, Politicians and Patriots|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=32l9iEyKUxkC&pg=PA160|accessdate=8 October 2011|year=2005|publisher=The History Press|isbn=978-1-59629-055-6|pages=160, 272}}</ref> Their daughter, Mary Moore, married Job Howe, another of the "Goose Creek Men".<ref name="Heitzler2005-160"/> Altogether James and Margaret had ten children, many of whom moved to the [[Cape Fear (region)|Lower Cape Fear]] region, where they and their descendants became known as "The Family", the most powerful family in the region.<ref name="OlwellTully2006">{{cite book|last1=Olwell|first1=Robert|last2=Tully|first2=Alan|title=Cultures and identities in colonial British America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6XqEkzVWNnkC&pg=PA60|accessdate=8 October 2011|year=2006|publisher=JHU Press|isbn=978-0-8018-8251-7|pages=60–61}}</ref> Moore was the grandfather of [[American Revolutionary War]] [[Brigadier General]] [[James Moore (Continental Army officer)|James Moore]], and great-grandfather of [[Major General]] [[Robert Howe (soldier)|Robert Howe]].
The Moore family imported over 4,000 [[African slavery|slaves]] into the Carolinas, mostly for its own extensive plantations and farms in and around the Cape Fear area of what later became North Carolina. James Moore also had a house in Charleston and another in the Goose Creek area near Charleston.
Another Moore family descendent, [[Alfred Moore]], became a Justice of the [[US Supreme Court]].
===Family tree===

{{About|a lawyer and Louisiana politician|James Eubanks, the professional ''Call of Duty'' player|Clayster}} {{Infobox Officeholder |name=James Rowland Eubank |image = |imagesize = |nationality=[[United States|American]] |office=[[Louisiana House of Representatives|Louisiana State Representative
for Rapides Parish]] |party=[[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] |term_start=May 1952 |term_end=November 9, 1952 |preceded=[[Lawrence T. Fuglaar]] [[W. George Bowdon, Jr.]]
[[T. C. Brister]] |succeeded=[[Lloyd George Teekell]] |birth_date={{birth date|1914|12|8}} |birth_place=Place of birth missing |death_date=November 9, 1952 (aged 37) |death_place=[[Alexandria, Louisiana|Alexandria]], [[Rapides Parish, Louisiana|Rapides Parish]]
[[Louisiana]], USA |death_cause=[[Myocardial infarction|Heart attack]] |resting_place=Greenwood Memorial Park in [[Pineville, Louisiana|Pineville]], Louisiana |alma_mater=[[Louisiana State University Law Center]] |occupation=[[Lawyer]] |residence=Alexandria, Louisiana |spouse=Katherine Bringhurst Eubank |children=Robert Benjamin Eubank
Elizabeth Tracy Eubank |parents=Maude Lee and Benjamin Franklin Eubank |relations=[[Swords Lee]] (maternal grandfather) |religion = |branch=[[United States Army]] |battles=[[World War II]] |footnotes= }} '''James Rowland Eubank''' (December 8, 1914 – November 9, 1952) was a [[lawyer]] from [[Alexandria, Louisiana|Alexandria]], [[Louisiana]], who served for six months during 1952 in the [[Louisiana House of Representatives]] for [[Rapides Parish, Louisiana|Rapides Parish]].{{cite web|url=http://house.louisiana.gov/H_PDFdocs/HouseMembership_History_CURRENT.pdf |title=Membership in the Louisiana House of Representatives, 1812-2012 |publisher=house.louisiana.gov |accessdate=December 28, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006105414/http://house.louisiana.gov/H_PDFdocs/HouseMembership_History_CURRENT.pdf |archivedate=October 6, 2014 |df= }} He died in office at the age of thirty-seven from a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]].{{cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/98916108|title=James Rowland Eubank|publisher=''[[The Advocate (Louisiana)|Baton Rouge Advocate]]''|date=November 10, 1952|accessdate=December 28, 2014}} Eubank was a floor leader for [[governor of Louisiana|Governor]] [[Robert F. Kennon]]. He was succeeded in the House by [[Lloyd George Teekell]], another Alexandria lawyer who won a [[special election]] in 1953 to fill the remaining three years of Eubank's term. Eubank was the only child of Maude Lee Eubank (1885-1958){{cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/98916110|title=Maude Lee Eubank|publisher=findagrave.com|accessdate=December 28, 2014}} and Benjamin Franklin Eubank (1882-1962), a former official of the Louisiana State Police and the state hospital system.{{cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/98916107|title=Benjamin Franklin Eubank|publisher=findagrave.com|accessdate=December 28, 2014}} Eubank and his wife, the former Katherine Bringhurst, had two children, Robert Benjamin Eubank (born 1942) and Elizabeth Tracy Eubank (born August 1943). Eubank was a maternal grandson of [[Swords Lee]], a timber businessman in [[Pollock, Louisiana|Pollock]] and Alexandria, who represented [[Grant Parish, Louisiana|Grant Parish]] in the Louisiana House from 1904 to 1908. He was a descendant of the [[Light Horse Harry Lee|Lee family]] of [[Virginia (U.S. state)|Virginia]]. His middle name is derived from his great-grandmother, Martha Roland Lee, spelled without the "w".{{cite web|url=http://files.usgwarchives.net/la/winn/obits/l/leesr229.txt|title=Col. Stephen R. Lee of Alexandria Dies at His Home Feb. 13: Industrial and Political Leader, Descendant of Famous Lees|date=February 22, 1929|publisher=''Winnfield News-American''|location=[[Winnfield, Louisiana|Winnfield]], [[Louisiana]]|accessdate=May 23, 2015}} Eubank served in the [[United States Army]] during [[World War II]]. He is interred alongside his parents at Greenwood Memorial Park in [[Pineville, Louisiana|Pineville]], Louisiana. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portalbar|Louisiana|Politics|Law|World War II|United States Army}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | before =[[W. George Bowdon, Jr.]]
[[T. C. Brister]]
[[Lawrence T. Fuglaar]] | title = [[Louisiana House of Representatives|Louisiana State Representative for Rapides Parish]] James Rowland Eubank
(alongside [[Cecil R. Blair]] and [[H. N. Goff]]) | years =May 1952–November 1952 | after =[[Lloyd George Teekell]]}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Eubank, James R.}} [[Category:1914 births]] [[Category:1952 deaths]] [[Category:Lee family of Virginia]] [[Category:Members of the Louisiana House of Representatives]] [[Category:Politicians from Alexandria, Louisiana]] [[Category:Louisiana Democrats]] [[Category:Louisiana State University Law Center alumni]] [[Category:Louisiana lawyers]] [[Category:United States Army soldiers]] [[Category:American army personnel of World War II]] [[Category:20th-century American lawyers]] [[Category:Burials in Louisiana]] {{louisiana-politician-stub}}
